name: Islamic Center of Irvine
mission: Mission statement - To establish a comprehensive center promoting Islamic values and reflecting excellence in serving the needs of the community
zakatClaimEvidence: 100% of the Islamic Center Of Irvine's Zakat fund goes towards providing zakat eligible members in the community. If you would like to contribute funds to help needy families you can do so by either donating your Zakat ul-Maal or your Sadaqah. (Source: https://icoi.net/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

all_citations.claim: The organization reports a program expense ratio of 89.9%, working capital of 26.3 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc reported total revenue of $2,209,994 and operates programs including The Village In Irvine and ICOI Young Professionals.
The organization offers various donation options and is designated as zakat-eligible.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its strong financial health and high program spending, balanced against a lack of independent third-party ratings and moderate donor alignment.
areas_for_improvement: Limited external third-party impact evaluations or standardized ratings
Opportunities to increase transparency regarding specific program outcomes

dimension_explanations.alignment: ICOI shows medium donor alignment as a religious and cultural institution that provides zakat-eligible giving options for the Muslim community [3]. While it maintains a clear mission, the urgency is categorized as religious-cultural rather than emergency-based [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The center demonstrates high capacity-building potential by allocating 89.9% of its $2,209,994 revenue toward programs like the ICOI Young Professionals [1][2]. Its financial stability is evidenced by 26.3 months of working capital, ensuring long-term operational sustainability [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc serves as a comprehensive community hub dedicated to promoting Islamic values through robust social and professional programming.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.9%, indicating the vast majority of funds go directly to services
Strong liquidity with 26.3 months of working capital available
Exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.00 spent per $1 raised
baseline_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc (ICOI) operates with a mission to serve community needs through excellence and Islamic values, reporting a total revenue of $2,209,994 [1][2]. The organization facilitates various community initiatives, including 'The Village In Irvine' and 'ICOI Young Professionals,' while maintaining zakat-eligible status for donors [2][3].

case_against.summary: The primary limitations involve <cite id="13">limited external impact evaluations</cite> and a lack of standardized outcome reporting.

confidence.notes: Strong financial efficiency data, but impact measurement is limited by lack of beneficiary reporting.

alignment.explanation: The center offers <cite id="7">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serves the specific religious and social needs of the <cite id="1">Orange County Muslim community</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="8">zakat allocation policy</cite> and specific eligible use categories would further enhance donor alignment.

credibility.explanation: Donors can find confidence in ICOI's <cite id="10">fully independent board</cite> and its <cite id="15">Bronze Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>. The organization's financial data is publicly accessible via <cite id="2">Form 990 filings</cite>, showing consistent asset management.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the center could <cite id="13">publish annual impact reports</cite> that include specific beneficiary counts and audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by an <cite id="5">89.9% program ratio</cite> and a capacity-building model. However, the <cite id="14">absence of a theory of change</cite> limits the ability to measure long-term efficacy.
impact.improvement: The organization should <cite id="14">document a clear theory of change</cite> with an explicit causal pathway to better communicate its community impact.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value local community infrastructure and want to support a financially stable, zakat-eligible hub in Southern California.
donor_motivations: Want to support local Muslim youth and professional development
Value high financial efficiency and low overhead
Seek to fulfill zakat through a verified community center
Prefer organizations with strong independent board oversight
giving_considerations: Donations support a broad range of community services rather than a single niche project
The organization is in a growth phase with a 10.6% revenue CAGR
Impact is measured through community participation rather than RCT-level data
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking international emergency relief or those who require rigorous third-party academic impact evaluations.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects strong financial transparency and program service reporting, but a lack of standardized outcome metrics or external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: ICOI creates impact by providing a physical and social space for religious education, professional networking, and social services, assuming these activities strengthen community cohesion.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that community programs are effectively meeting the spiritual and social needs of the congregation.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a growing community center with a 10.6% revenue CAGR, additional funding supports the expansion of youth and professional programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by <cite id="6">zero-cost fundraising efficiency</cite> and exceptionally high <cite id="9">working capital reserves</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="5">89.9% of its total expenses</cite> toward its core community programs and services.
ICOI reports a <cite id="6">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, maximizing the impact of every dollar donated.
The center maintains <cite id="9">26.3 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, providing significant long-term stability.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Center of Irvine exhibits strong financial governance, characterized by a <cite id="10">100% independent board of directors</cite> consisting of 9 members. This oversight supports a sustainable growth model, evidenced by <cite id="11">net assets totaling $4,758,051</cite> as of 2022. The organization's ability to scale is reflected in its <cite id="4">10.6% revenue growth rate</cite> over three years, while maintaining a lean administrative structure. Beyond local services, ICOI also acts as a community benefactor, distributing <cite id="12">$31,500 in domestic grants</cite> to partner Islamic institutions, further strengthening the regional Muslim infrastructure.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc (ICOI) serves as a vital community hub in Orange County, California, dedicated to <cite id="1">promoting Islamic values and reflecting excellence</cite> in its service delivery. The organization manages a diverse portfolio of social and professional initiatives, including <cite id="2">The Village In Irvine and ICOI Young Professionals</cite>, which cater to various demographic needs within the local Muslim community. Financially, the center demonstrated consistent growth, reporting <cite id="3">total revenue of $2,209,994</cite> in its most recent filing, representing a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 10.6%</cite>. A defining characteristic of ICOI is its operational efficiency; the organization maintains a <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 89.9%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor contributions directly support community services. Furthermore, the center operates with <cite id="6">exceptional fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending $0.00 to raise every $1 in contributions. As a <cite id="7">zakat-eligible institution</cite>, ICOI provides a verified pathway for donors to fulfill their religious obligations, specifically supporting categories such as <cite id="8">the poor (fuqara), the needy (masakin), and the wayfarer (ibn sabil)</cite>.
